gamehuis
 
 Aside from trying to pick up chics on this board, I would have thought you a bit more savvy with your links.
 
It will be the president's 50th trip to the ranch since he was elected nearly five years ago.
 
 McClellan said Bush looks forward to being able to "shed the coat and tie" at his more casual home near the small town of Crawford, Texas. Bush plans to travel to seven states from the ranch and hold at least 10 events to tout his agenda, including the war on terror and his economic priorities.
 
 Members of Congress can pick among meetings to reacquaint themselves with their constitutents, march in parades and attend barbecuers and, doubtless, take some official trips as well.
 
 Bush's first speech from his away-from-Washington life will be Wednesday, just about 150 miles up the road in the Dallas suburb of Grapevine. Bush plans to speak to the American Legislative Exchange Council, a conservative-leaning, bipartisan group of state lawmakers and business leaders.
 
 On Thursday, Bush plans to host Colombian President Alvaro Uribe at his ranch.

 
 First thing first, the ranch in question at Crawford is his home. The whitehouse is home away from home. So the guy returns home once a month. Shame on him! emoticon_rolleyes
 There is life inside the bubble of the beltway, and real life beyond. He is a Texan, he should return.
 And even then, this, like all the other, is still a working trip: 10 events to meet with his constituents, and a visit with a foreign leader.
 Seems to me all work.
 
 If you ever been on one, you would know that business trips even to nice locales remain work and not vacation.

No you're just alone in not being able to put out a rational explanation backed up with concrete facts for why you think this juvenile tirade has a point.

 
 Concrete facts? Is GWB or is GWB not at his place of work? It seems your president is not working hard enough. Too fond of being away from the capital, not interested in leading from the front.
 
 The Presidency - Good Work If You Can Get It

It would seem that, in truth, Bush's people HAVE NOT been informing him when disasters or potential disasters occur.
 
 It appears that there may have been a 30 minute lag before Bush was notified that the 9/11 attacks had occurred--or that there were some very strange deviations in flight patterns for several commercial flights. I believe that only the President of the United States is the only official who has the power to tell the Air Force or whatever to shoot down a suspicious plane.

Bush was cycling with a friend several miles away from the White House and could easily have been informed about the presence of the craft.
 
 Frankly, Bush appears to totally out of the loop on a lot of things.

You have failed to point out what in particular in necessary about him being in DC as he actually leads the entire nation. Just to make another point lost on you apparently in the nuclear age there is a certain level of security provided by moving the President around from place to place on a short notification schedule as it makes it difficult to be precisely sure where he will be. Not that this matters to the side of the debate that continues to enagae in pointless infantile comments.

Strange, the pres can be anywhere but at his desk, and so ardent are his supporters that they see this as "business as usual". Anywhere else, it would be a cause for concern. Am I alone in expecting more than 9 - 5, mon - fri attitude from George Walker Bush?

 
 
 Bush is not the decision maker, he is the PR guy. He is told what he "needs" to know, and is told what decisions to make. Which means Bush can be "Working his Ranch" and be briefed in 10 minutes so he can make one of his rare ( for a president ) question periods by the news media.

Clearly you just insist on being thick headed. It has been pointed out that the President can be in communication with anyone he needs to be from anywhere he goes. You have failed to point out what in particular in necessary about him being in DC as he actually leads the entire nation.

Since face to face communication and proximity to others is no longer necessary due to modern communications, why not, in this time of record deficits, shut down the white house (maybe make it a Bed and Breakfast), the congressional buildings and related offices, send the congress and staffs back to their respective states, and let Dubya stay in Crawford.  Perhaps the president, because he's not a city/urban type of guy and likes a naturalistic setting to work because it allows him to work more effectively, feels he can better serve the nation by carrying out his duties at his ranch. Personally, if he feels like he's doing better presiding from his ranch, more power to him. I see no evidence that he's doing a poorer job presiding because he's there.

 Where is here? You don't seem to want to display your location. We all know there's more than one way to become an American citizen. That said, as an American citizen, English is the native tongue. It's the primary language taught in American schools and it's how our government communicates with its citizenry. I'm not really interested in debating this topic with you, it probably should be a thread unto itself. I think Dono was merely pointing out that if you want to make a "snippy" reply, it carries more weight when correctly spelled.

 Take Bill Clinton for example, he only went on vacation for 152 days during 7 years in office. GW broke that record after only 3 years.[/QUOTE]

 Our economy and currency have been in decline since the early 1970s due to the move to a global economy and our unsustainable general standard of living based on public and personal debt. Current administration has gone far beyond all prior administrations with irresponsibility in the accumulation of public debt, government expansion and service of special interests. Unless current administration achieves some sort of economic miracle like turning water into oil, history books will not view it in a favorable light.

Workers with 401 pick a letter scams encouraged and managed by people who make money regardless of which way a market swings took the brunt of equity losses, not anyone familiar enough with finance to understand no earnings mean eventual insolvency.

Ever hear of the Teapot Dome Scandal? Or innumerable other public scams? One thing that has never changed is public ability to take big hits and keep coming back for more in their desire to get something for nothing.

 Two-year AAA munis here are now 5.8%, tax free. Two-year Fed treasuries, 3.875%. Duh, munis with better returns than historical equity market returns says a bunch. 
 
 And you're very correct about expansion capital; most US corporations are awash with cash and no place to put it. Forget borrowing for expansion. Take a longer vacation.

A recession began at the end of Clinton's presidency and accelerated post-9/11. It is now picking up with 207,000 new jobs being created in July and talk of increasing the interest rate to slow growth.

 Increasing the interest rate is to keep foreign money financing our increasing debt. Let's examine the jobs bottom line with the following quotes:
 Some recent headlines suggest this divided reality: "Layoffs abundant despite good economic outlook," reads one; "Honeywell posts strong sales, confirms layoffs," declares a second. Or: "Consumers are anxious, while investors are confident this month."
 
 In late July, on the eve of a Federal Reserve survey indicating that "economic activity continued to expand in June and early July," US corporations announced tens of thousands of new layoffs.
 
 Despite the upbeat central bank report, which pointed to "factories buzzing" and "cash registers ringing," in the words of one press account, the relentless attack on secure, decent jobs continues in the US. And on workers' incomes. While executive compensation continues to soar, the Federal Reserve reports contentedly, "Despite generally tighter labor markets, nearly all Districts said overall wage pressures remained moderate"-i.e., workers' wages continue to stagnate or actually fall behind the rate of inflation.
 
 Fast on the heels of the announcement by printer and computer maker Hewlett-Packard that it would lay off 14,500 workers, corporate giants Eastman Kodak and Kimberly-Clark revealed plans for more massive job-cutting.
 
 After its third straight quarterly loss, a loss that exceeded investors' forecasts, Eastman Kodak management declared July 19 that it would lay off as many as 10,000 workers from its worldwide workforce, in addition to the 15,000 already announced in January 2004. The company, based in Rochester, New York, blamed the loss on a rapid decline in revenue from traditional film and other chemical-based businesses.
 
 On July 22 Kimberly-Clark, the maker of Kleenex tissues and Huggies diapers, announced plans to cut 6,000 jobs and sell or shut down as many as 20 manufacturing plants during the next three-and-a-half years.Based in Irving, Texas, Kimberly-Clark reported that earnings for the second quarter fell slightly due to a tax expense; sales rose 8 percent. The job reductions will result in a loss of about 10 percent of its workforce. Some 17 percent of the company's plants will be closed or sold; in addition, four facilities will be streamlined and seven others expanded.
 
 The Wall Street Journal reported July 22 that Ford Motor Co. was considering cutting as many as 30 percent of its white-collar workforce-some 10,500 of its 35,000 salaried workers-in North America over the next few years.
 
 Company spokesman Oscar Suris would not confirm the report, but he noted that earlier in the week Ford Chief Financial Officer Don Leclair had said "nothing is off the table" when asked about possible cuts. Ford has already announced plans to reduce its salaried labor force by 2,700 by the end of 2005.
 
 Computer printer maker Lexmark, which supplies products to Dell and competes with Hewlett-Packard, revealed plans July 26 to cut 275 jobs to reduce costs. The company had 13,400 workers at the end of 2004.
 
 Ben Dobbin, in a widely republished Associated Press story, observed that "some economy watchers are suddenly concerned that this latest flurry of job cuts-a byproduct of various trends such as outsourcing, mergers, automation, changing technology and consumer demands-may foreshadow some trouble ahead. " 'We won't know till afterwards, but I do think we may be seeing a tipping point in the economic cycle that these big layoffs are flagging,' said John A. Carpenter, chief executive of Challenger, Gray & Christmas, a Chicago-based employment research firm. 'I think it's a sign that leaks are breaking out.' "One thing is for certain: It was not a good week for American labor. In fact, it's been an unusually torrid summer in terms of trimming payrolls. "US corporations announced plans in June to cut 110,996 jobs-the highest monthly total in 17 months-and July's toll could turn out to be steeper. Overall job cuts are on the rise in 2005, reaching 538,274 through June, according to Challenger's monthly job-cut analysis."
 
 "A few sectors continue to reliably create jobs, especially health care and construction. Professional services, a large and important sector that had been adding jobs steadily in recent months, shed 1,000 jobs last month. Information services, another high-end sector, also reversed course and lost 8,000 jobs last month, its worst showing since last September. Temporary work, a source of growth earlier in the recovery, has been essentially flat since last November."
 
 Dono

We are raising interest rates, and will ocntinue to do so, because the asians have threatened to stop buying our bonds.

 
 
 Quite right, from being 1% lower then equivalent Canadian bond rates about 1.5 years ago, to being 1% higher then the Canadian bond rates. The CAD has been relatively stable in value compared to the USD, official inflation rates roughly equal

Professional services, a large and important sector that had been adding jobs steadily in recent months, shed 1,000 jobs last month. Temporary work, a source of growth earlier in the recovery, has been essentially flat since last November."

 A lot of what we're seeing is the long-term impact of legacy costs. Despite record sales, many industries are also experiencing record legacy costs from healthcare and other retirement benefits.
 In the auto industry, Ford, DCX and GM still have workforces sized for their marketshares of the past decade. They have to shed white and blue collar workers in order to begin to compete with foreign competitors that don't have high legacy costs...yet.
 Here in Michigan, we have a shortage of medical doctors. there are ~30,000 but a need for ~37,000. We also have a fairly large contingency of Canadian healthcare workers who make the trip across the border daily because there aren't enough qualified nurses, etc., in the States.

Here in Michigan, we have a shortage of medical doctors. there are ~30,000 but a need for ~37,000. We also have a fairly large contingency of Canadian healthcare workers who make the trip across the border daily because there aren't enough qualified nurses, etc., in the States.

 
 I believe that's a result of Canadian public health care. Their government job market from doctor to janitor has been saturated or/and US positions pay better due to the scarcity of US healthcare workers. We haven't gotten all that deep into socialism but our educational system is in the process of expanding public health service workers. Which is coming as a shock to most states as the feds dump former federal health care costs to state levels in order to maintain a strong military apparatus.

A lot of what we're seeing is the long-term impact of legacy costs. Despite record sales, many industries are also experiencing record legacy costs from healthcare and other retirement benefits.
 

 
 To further simplify, we could just say that domestic manufacturers are saddled with expensive labor costs that aren't competitive in a global market. American workers have priced themselves out of the world market. When trying to figure in the higher cost of American wages and benefits, our products will never be competitive with the cheaper imports flooding in from newly emerging industrialized nations. Jobs in the service industry are safe for now only because we haven't found a way to import foreign accountants lawyers and plumbers. The long term implications will be realized when there aren't enough wage earners at the working level to sustain these services. I don't want to trivialize your point on legacy costs, but the high cost of even entry level labor in many industries is still not competitive with our foreign trading partners.
